intro.para:
Our work environment In this chapter we will introduce our work environment, a ‘straight’ and ‘endless’ n-dimensional space \RNr[n] for each natural number n. A point in \RNr[n] is given by n numbers x_1,\dots ,x_n
written in order as (x_1,\dots ,x_n)
Such a string of n numbers is called an n-tuple. – See some examples.
. We will study in detail how to use such points to describe objects like lines and planes in \RNr[n]. We will learn how to move such objects around and how to change their shape. We will learn general rules on how to compute with such points. Beyond this, the space \RNr[n] has a dimension, namely n, a concept which can be explained at an intuitive level:

On the dimension concept For a natural number n, a space is called n-dimensional if, at each of its points, it permits exactly n independent directions of motion which can be combined to reach any nearby point. For example,

li.para: A single point is a 0-dimensional space, as it permits no motion inside of it at all.

A line or a curve are 1-dimensional spaces: inside of it, at each of its points, there is exactly one direction of motion. It could be called forward-backward
An illustration of a 1-dimensional space
.

A plane or a surface are 2-dimensional spaces: inside of it, at each of its points, there are exactly two independent directions of motion. These could be called forward-backward and left-right
An illustration of a 2-dimensional space
. Every other direction of motion can be combined from these two.

The space surrounding us is 3-dimensional: inside of it, at each of its points, there are exactly three independent directions of motion. These could be called forward-backward, left-right, and up-down. Every other direction of motion can be combined from these three.

intro.para:
In popular literature some mystery surrounds the concept of 4-dimensional and even higher dimensional spaces. Let us say for now: such spaces exist. Once we learn how to identify them, we find them all around us, and we use them all the time. – So why are they mysterious? They are pushed into mystery because they are
not accessible to our visual sense
See details on this.
!
Chapter summary Let us now summarize the essence of this introductory chapter to the vector space \RNr[n].

li.para:
We begin by introducing the concept of
n-tuple of numbers
See some examples of n-tuples
. The collection of all n-tuples is the
space \RNr[n]
See illustrations of \RNr[1], \RNr[2], and \RNr[3].
. We then use the product operation on sets to see that \StPrdct{ \RNr[m] }{ \RNr[n] } = \RNr[m+n].

We introduce a notion of distance between two points P and Q in \RNr[n].
It is based on the Theorem of Pythagoras
An illustration of the formula for the distance between two points
.

To be able to make a transition from one point P to another Q, we introduce the arrow \Arrw{PQ} from P, its tail, to Q its tip. The length of \Arrw{PQ} is the distance between P and Q. An arrow is determined by its tail point, its direction, and its length. A vector consists of all arrows of given direction and length. We may
describe it
See a detailed example.
using a coordinate n-tuple. Thus a coordinate n-tuple now serves two purposes: locate a point, describe a vector. We explain how these two purposes are related.

Next we explain how two vectors can be
added
See an illustration
, and how a
vector is multiplied by a number
Some examples of multiplying a vector by a number.
. Each of these operations has a useful geometric interpretation. Moreover, they satisfy rules which resemble the rules for adding and multiplying numbers.
Using these vector operations we learn about linear motions in space: the motion of a particle along a straight line and with constant speed.
